item.title: Abiral Bagdachha Indrawati - Episode 1
item.ns0:subtitle: Abiral Bagdacha Indrawati Intro
item.description: Abiral Bagdachha Indrawati - Episode 1 Report issues with episodes at https://github.com/abpaudel/nepali-audiobooks/issues. Nepali Novel Abiral Bagdacha Indrawati is Written by Ramesh Vikal Flowing is a feature of the river. Because that's his regularity. His character is to kiss the blue of the ocean with the first flow, avoiding the contingency of obstruction. In some rivers, life flows along with the water. In Indravati, the sweat of fishermen and danuvars has been flowing for centuries. And so, its color is pure blue, to this day. Holding Indravati's broken arm in her arms and throwing a net in the daha, playing ruthless Singauri with water, returning the dhuvali, tapping the bait and catching all the fish and ganga as a gift from Indravati from Udayachal to Astachal. When the Sahu-Mahajans do not get bored only after losing their birauta, whether it is snowing the Indravati river or crossing the river to the passers-by in a boat, they save their livelihood. Ramesh Vikal wrote the endless story of the same fishermen who lived a miserable life relying on the same Indravati's neighbors instead of wandering in search of new means of livelihood. 'Aviral Bagdach Indravati' is the same sad story. It is the life of fishermen living from Sipaghat to Dolalghat. Vikal, who has been closely watching the innocent pleas of fishermen to make a living from Sahumahajan, has been struggling to write his stories since the 1930s. And so, Vikal says in the novel, "I looked closely at the life of a fisherman who cries and laughs for the existence of the land on the banks of the river Indravati. That is the gross expression - the novel 'Abiral Bagdacha Indrawati.' "Aviral Bagdach Indravati" is a Nepali language novel written by Ramesh Vikal and brought to the market by Sajha Prakashan. (Source: "Yasri Aviral Bagyo Indravati" Review Baharkhari.com) An audio book version in the voice of Khagendra Nepali has been collected. Episode description/links courtesy of https://hamroawaz.blogspot.com.

Nepali Novel Abiral Bagdacha Indrawati is Written by Ramesh Vikal Flowing is a feature of the river. Because that's his regularity. His character is to kiss the blue of the ocean with the first flow, avoiding the contingency of obstruction. In some rivers, life flows along with the water. In Indravati, the sweat of fishermen and danuvars has been flowing for centuries. And so, its color is pure blue, to this day. Holding Indravati's broken arm in her arms and throwing a net in the daha, playing ruthless Singauri with water, returning the dhuvali, tapping the bait and catching all the fish and ganga as a gift from Indravati from Udayachal to Astachal. When the Sahu-Mahajans do not get bored only after losing their birauta, whether it is snowing the Indravati river or crossing the river to the passers-by in a boat, they save their livelihood. Ramesh Vikal wrote the endless story of the same fishermen who lived a miserable life relying on the same Indravati's neighbors instead of wandering in search of new means of livelihood. 'Aviral Bagdach Indravati' is the same sad story. It is the life of fishermen living from Sipaghat to Dolalghat. Vikal, who has been closely watching the innocent pleas of fishermen to make a living from Sahumahajan, has been struggling to write his stories since the 1930s. And so, Vikal says in the novel, "I looked closely at the life of a fisherman who cries and laughs for the existence of the land on the banks of the river Indravati. That is the gross expression - the novel 'Abiral Bagdacha Indrawati.' "Aviral Bagdach Indravati" is a Nepali language novel written by Ramesh Vikal and brought to the market by Sajha Prakashan. (Source: "Yasri Aviral Bagyo Indravati" Review Baharkhari.com) An audio book version in the voice of Khagendra Nepali has been collected. Episode description/links courtesy of https://hamroawaz.blogspot.com.

Nepali Novel Abiral Bagdacha Indrawati is Written by Ramesh Vikal Flowing is a feature of the river. Because that's his regularity. His character is to kiss the blue of the ocean with the first flow, avoiding the contingency of obstruction. In some rivers, life flows along with the water. In Indravati, the sweat of fishermen and danuvars has been flowing for centuries. And so, its color is pure blue, to this day. Holding Indravati's broken arm in her arms and throwing a net in the daha, playing ruthless Singauri with water, returning the dhuvali, tapping the bait and catching all the fish and ganga as a gift from Indravati from Udayachal to Astachal. When the Sahu-Mahajans do not get bored only after losing their birauta, whether it is snowing the Indravati river or crossing the river to the passers-by in a boat, they save their livelihood. Ramesh Vikal wrote the endless story of the same fishermen who lived a miserable life relying on the same Indravati's neighbors instead of wandering in search of new means of livelihood. 'Aviral Bagdach Indravati' is the same sad story. It is the life of fishermen living from Sipaghat to Dolalghat. Vikal, who has been closely watching the innocent pleas of fishermen to make a living from Sahumahajan, has been struggling to write his stories since the 1930s. And so, Vikal says in the novel, "I looked closely at the life of a fisherman who cries and laughs for the existence of the land on the banks of the river Indravati. That is the gross expression - the novel 'Abiral Bagdacha Indrawati.' "Aviral Bagdach Indravati" is a Nepali language novel written by Ramesh Vikal and brought to the market by Sajha Prakashan. (Source: "Yasri Aviral Bagyo Indravati" Review Baharkhari.com) An audio book version in the voice of Khagendra Nepali has been collected. Episode description/links courtesy of https://hamroawaz.blogspot.com.

Nepali Novel Abiral Bagdacha Indrawati is Written by Ramesh Vikal Flowing is a feature of the river. Because that's his regularity. His character is to kiss the blue of the ocean with the first flow, avoiding the contingency of obstruction. In some rivers, life flows along with the water. In Indravati, the sweat of fishermen and danuvars has been flowing for centuries. And so, its color is pure blue, to this day. Holding Indravati's broken arm in her arms and throwing a net in the daha, playing ruthless Singauri with water, returning the dhuvali, tapping the bait and catching all the fish and ganga as a gift from Indravati from Udayachal to Astachal. When the Sahu-Mahajans do not get bored only after losing their birauta, whether it is snowing the Indravati river or crossing the river to the passers-by in a boat, they save their livelihood. Ramesh Vikal wrote the endless story of the same fishermen who lived a miserable life relying on the same Indravati's neighbors instead of wandering in search of new means of livelihood. 'Aviral Bagdach Indravati' is the same sad story. It is the life of fishermen living from Sipaghat to Dolalghat. Vikal, who has been closely watching the innocent pleas of fishermen to make a living from Sahumahajan, has been struggling to write his stories since the 1930s. And so, Vikal says in the novel, "I looked closely at the life of a fisherman who cries and laughs for the existence of the land on the banks of the river Indravati. That is the gross expression - the novel 'Abiral Bagdacha Indrawati.' "Aviral Bagdach Indravati" is a Nepali language novel written by Ramesh Vikal and brought to the market by Sajha Prakashan. (Source: "Yasri Aviral Bagyo Indravati" Review Baharkhari.com) An audio book version in the voice of Khagendra Nepali has been collected. Episode description/links courtesy of https://hamroawaz.blogspot.com.
